content:
Test 4 is very strange with the "1 1" case...
If the expected roll is 1, then you'd think that would mean success, but your code wants it to be called a "Critical Failure".

I submitted my code in a clash without noticing that I failed the last test (too trigger happy), but then I still got 100% because none of your validators test for this edge case.

You should probably add a similar validator that includes "1 1" if you want this edge case to matter. But it seems to me that it's not a realistic situation to have a 20-sided die whose expected result is 1 and for which 1 is also a critical failure...

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice one, well explained, short enough while putting a little twist with critical rolls. the tests cover the edge cases

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: good

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice one, short enough and I think be funny in short code

Goal section
* Please format "Success", "Failure", "Critical Success" and "Critical Failure" as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks.

Input section
* Please add "space-separated" between "two" and "integers".

Constraints section
* I think you've mixed up "roll" and "nbRoll".

All sections
* Please standardise the terms: call DC either "required value" or "expected value".

Stub generator
* Please provide two ints instead of a string.

Thanks.

Done, thank you ðŸ˜Š
I just didn't achieve to do what you suggested on the stub generator. I wanted to do something like 
```
loop nbRoll read x:int read y:int
```
but this (and all my other attempts) didn't work, so I ended up providing a string because that's what I usually see on CoC stubs

It should be:
loop nbRoll read x:int y:int
